question_text: How does Fermi level tuning through chemical functionalization enhance the built-in potential and power conversion efficiency in nanocarbon-based planar heterojunction solar cells?
standard_answer: Fermi level tuning in graphene and carbon nanotubes via chemical functionalization enhances the built-in potential and power conversion efficiency (PCE) by increasing charge carrier density and optimizing band alignment at the heterojunction interface. Doping shifts the Fermi level, which directly influences the built-in potential (V_bi) according to the relation V_bi = (E_F,nanocarbon - E_F,semiconductor)/q, where E_F is the Fermi level and q is the electron charge. For p-type doping with molecules like HNO3 or SOCl2, electrons are extracted from nanocarbons, lowering their Fermi level and increasing V_bi, leading to higher open-circuit voltage (V_oc). This is supported by the paper's discussion: 'The HNO3 doping reduced the sheet resistance of the CNT film and significantly decreased the series resistance... The HNO3 doping also shifted the Fermi level of CNTs downwards, resulting in the increased built-in potential and V_oc of the CNT/Si PHJ solar cell.' Additionally, increased carrier density improves electrical conductivity, reducing series resistance and enhancing fill factor. The mechanism involves charge transfer at the nanocarbon surface, where dopants create electron-acceptor or donor states, modifying the density of states near the Dirac point. For instance, heavy p-doping can induce a p-type inversion layer in n-Si, forming an equivalent p-n junction, further boosting V_bi. The paper notes: 'The heavily p-doped SWNT film could induce a p-type inversion layer onto the surface of the n-type Si, resulting in an equivalent p–n junction at room temperature.' This synergistic effect of reduced resistance and optimized band alignment collectively elevates PCE by improving both V_oc and short-circuit current (J_sc).
